questions.text: Which of the given instrument's tip resembles the given image?

Match the following Blade numbers with their uses given. 1. No. 11 a) Skin incisions in major surgeries 2. No. 12 b) Used in plastic surgery 3. No. 15 c) Incision and drainage of abscesses 4. No. 22 d) Used for tonsillectomy
questions.explanation:
Blade Number

Use

No. 11

Stab knife, used for incision and drainage of abscesses, and small incisions (e.g., drains).

No. 12

Curved blade, used for tonsillectomy; cutting edge faces the surgeon.

No. 15

Used in plastic surgery, head and neck surgeries, and facial surgeries.

Nos. 20, 22, 24

Used for skin incisions in major surgeries like laparotomy, thoracotomy, craniotomy, and limb surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The needle holder is sterilized by an autoclave.

options.label: B
options.text: Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels.

options.label: C
options.text: Curved needle holders provide better maneuverability in deep areas like the pelvis.

options.label: D
options.text: Plain non-toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold friable structures like peritoneum and tendons.

questions.correct_answer: B. Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels.
questions.explanation:
INSTRUMENT

DESCRIPTION

NEEDLE HOLDER FORCEPS
  • Small distal blades with criss-cross serrations and a groove for grip.
  • Length of handle: Blade Ratio: 4:1.
  • Types: Straight or curved
  • Needle Positioning: Needle held at the junction of proximal 2/3 and distal 1/3 for control.
  • Handling: Held between thumb and ring finger.
  • Curved Holders: For better maneuverability in deep areas (pelvis, thorax). (Option C ruled out)
  • Sterilization: Autoclave. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tungsten-Carbide Coating: Increases durability.

PLAIN DISSECTING FORCEPS


 
  • Used to hold delicate, soft, and friable structures like peritoneum, vessels, bowel, nerves, and tendons. (Option D ruled out)
  • Not suitable for holding skin or tough structures.
  • Hold, fix, steady, or stretch tissues.
  • Hold and cauterize small bleeding vessels.

TOOTHED FORCEPS
  • Used to hold skin and tough structures like fascia and aponeurosis.
  • Not used for delicate structures like the bowel, vessels, or nerves. (Option B)
  • May have one-in-two or two-in-three teeth.
  • Adson’s Forceps: Small, fine forceps for delicate work; can be toothed or non-toothed.
  • Victor–Bonney’s Forceps: Heavy-toothed dissecting forceps.

questions.text: Match the following instruments with their corresponding images: 1) a) Bone nibbler 2) b) Humby’s Knife 3) c) Rib Shear 4) d) Bone Cutter
questions.explanation:
INSTRUMENT

DESCRIPTION

HUMBY’S KNIFE
  • Used for harvesting split skin grafts, usually from the thigh.
  • Parts: Stout handle with two flat blades, one fixed and one rotatable.
  • Disposable blade is secured with knobs for grafting.
  • Firm pressure with sawing action is used for skin harvesting.
  • Punctate bleeding confirms a successful graft.
  • Graft placed on a sterile board with small cuts to prevent seroma.
  • Fixed to the recipient site with sutures or staples.
  • Inspected on the 5th day for graft take-up.
  • The donor site is inspected after 10 days and left open.
  • Graft stages: plasmatic imbibition, revascularization, circulation.

RIB SHEAR
  • Large rough handles for better grip.
  • One blade is blunt with grooves and serrations, used as a protector for adjacent tissues.
  • The other blade is sharp and cuts the rib.
  • Designed to cut the rib from the front.
  • Used specifically for rib resection.

BONE / RIB CUTTER
  • Short blades with sharp, firm cutting edges for cutting bones.
  • Stout handle with ridges for a firm grip.
  • Provides optimal mechanical force for cutting bones or bone spurs.
  • Some models include a leverage system for enhanced performance.

BONE NIBBLER
  • Sharp edges at the tip with concave blades.
  • Available in single action or double action joint.
  • Used to nibble bone into pieces.
  • Commonly used in craniectomy, rib resection, and small bone amputations.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with rectal bleeding and a history of hemorrhoids. His physician decides to perform a proctoscopy using Kelly's rectal speculum to assess the cause of the bleeding. Which of the following is NOT an indication of the use of Kelly's rectal speculum?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic:

  • Piles (Option A ruled out)
  • Fissure in ano
  • Polyps
  • Stricture
  • Internal opening in fistula
  • Carcinoma or any rectal bleeding (Option D ruled out)

Therapeutic:

  • Injection therapy for partial prolapse or piles (Option B ruled out)
  • Cryotherapy for piles
  • Banding for piles
  • Polypectomy
  • Biopsy for carcinoma rectum or anorectum.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman undergoes surgery for varicose veins involving the stripping of the long saphenous vein using a Mayo vein stripper. Post-operatively, she complains of pain and tingling along the medial aspect of her leg. Which nerve is most commonly damaged during the stripping of the long saphenous vein?
Match the following instruments with their respective images: 1. Kocher’s forceps A) 2. Mosquito forceps B) 3. Allis forceps C) 4. Babcock’s forceps D)
Which of the following is used to retract the scapula during thoracotomy?
Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Mayo scissors from Metzenbaum scissors?

options.label: A
options.text: Mayo scissors are designed for delicate dissection while Metzenbaum scissors are sturdy and suited for cutting dense tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work.

options.label: C
options.text: Metzenbaum scissors are used for cutting dense tissues, while Mayo scissors are for blunt dissection in thoracic surgeries.

options.label: D
options.text: Metzenbaum scissors are suitable for cutting sutures and are sturdy, whereas Mayo scissors are delicate and used for blunt dissection

questions.correct_answer: B. Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work.
questions.explanation:
Scissors Type

Design

Uses

Alternative Names

Mayo Scissors

Sturdy and robust, suitable for cutting dense tissues.
  • Appendectomy.
  • Herniotomy.
  • Exploratory laparotomy.
  • Mastectomy.
  • Gynecological surgeries (e.g., dissecting tendons, and uterus structures).
  • Cutting ligaments (e.g., laryngectomy, thyroidectomy).

Often called "suture scissors".

Metzenbaum Scissors

Delicate and ideal for blunt dissection.
  • Blunt dissection.
  • Incising deep rib bed periosteum in thoracic procedures.
  • Tonsillectomy

Commonly known as "Metz" or "Lahey forceps".

Lister Bandage Scissors

Features a longer, blunt-tipped bottom blade paired with an angled sharp upper blade for secure and precise cutting.
  • Cutting bandages on the skin.
  • Dressings.

-

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is used to assess the patency of CBD?
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

Primary Use

Bakes Dilator / Bakes bile duct dilator
(Option A)

A long, malleable, metallic instrument with a club-shaped tip.

Assessing patency/blockage of the CBD and duodenal papilla.

Tracheal Dilator

(Option B ruled out)

Used to widen the tracheal opening during tracheostomy.

Facilitates insertion of a tracheostomy tube.

Urethral Dilator

(Option C ruled out)

A long, curved, metallic instrument with a blunt tip.

Urethral dilation.

questions.text: Which laparoscopic instrument is used to establish pneumoperitoneum?
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

Primary Use

Veress Needle

(Option B)

Spring-loaded with a sharp outer bevel and blunt inner stylet. Inserted at Palmer's point (3 cm below the left costal margin).

 

Establishes pneumoperitoneum for laparoscopic procedures.

Hasson Cannula/Trocar

(Option A ruled out)

A blunt-tipped trocar is inserted through a surgically created opening, typically at the umbilicus.


 

Used for open technique access in laparoscopy.

Trocar (Secondary)

(Option D ruled out)

Inserted under direct laparoscopic vision after pneumoperitoneum is established. Smaller diameters are preferred.

 


 

Allows insertion of additional instruments.

Laparoscopic Camera

(Option C)

Provides a magnified, real-time view of the surgical field.


 

Visualises the surgical field during laparoscopic surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the safety protocols for electrosurgery using diathermy?

options.label: A
options.text: Always use the maximum current setting to ensure effectiveness and minimize burns.

options.label: B
options.text: Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants.

options.label: C
options.text: Monopolar diathermy is preferred near vital & sensitive structures.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no need to use smoke extractors as the risk of exposure to surgical smoke is minimal.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Equipment Check: Verify settings before use.
  • ↳ Lowest Effective Setting : Use minimal current necessary. (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ :
  • ↳ (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Caution with Metal Objects : Be careful near other metal instruments.
  • ↳ :
  • ↳ Intermittent Use : Apply in short, controlled bursts.
  • ↳ :
  • ↳ Bipolar Preference: Prefer bipolar in sensitive areas or for patients with implants. (Option B)
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Smoke Evacuation: Use smoke extractors to reduce exposure to surgical smoke. (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given instrument?

options.label: A
options.text: Uses pressure and continuous bipolar energy for vessel sealing.

options.label: B
options.text: Achieves burst pressures over three times the normal systolic blood pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Denatures collagen and elastin in vessel walls, forming a solid tissue seal.
